user_message:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of dir_reader: ```c static ssize_t dir_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max) { DIR *dir = cls; struct dirent *e; int res; if (max < 512) return 0; (void) pos; /* 'pos' is ignored as function return next one single entry per call. */ do { e = readdir (dir); if (e == NULL) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM; } while (e->d_name[0] == '.'); res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name); if (0 >= res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; if (max < (size_t) res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; return (ssize_t) res; } ``` Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c do { e = readdir (dir); if (e == NULL) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM; } while (e->d_name[0] == '.'); ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
scenario: Not violated. The do/while body is reachable: each loop iteration assigns e = readdir(dir) and returns if e == NULL; otherwise the while condition checks e->d_name[0] == '.' so the loop exits when a non-dot entry is found and execution continues after the loop. There is no statement in this fragment that can never be executed. (A hypothetical violation would require code that is provably impossible to reach for all program executions—for example if an unconditional return were placed before some statements, making them never reachable; that is not the case here.)
